intro: Absinthium laxum, commonly known as slender wormwood, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and parts of western Asia. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and thrives in sunny environments. Its leaves are narrow and grass-like, while its flowers are small and yellow, often arranged in clusters. Absinthium laxum is sometimes used in traditional herbal medicine for its purported digestive and antiseptic properties.
distribution_native_art_desc: Absinthium laxum is primarily native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia, including countries such as Kazakhstan, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan. It thrives in alpine and subalpine environments, often found in rocky soils at elevations ranging from 1,500 to 3,500 meters. This plant is also present in parts of southern Russia and the Caucasus region. It is commonly found in meadows, slopes, and along riverbanks in these areas. Its distribution is closely linked to the cold, arid climates typical of its native habitat.

It was originally native to Europe and parts of Asia but has since spread to various regions. This plant is commonly found in disturbed soils, such as roadsides, fields, and along stream banks.
